repnme.cdata!:
Guinea - Village Communities Support
            Program (Phase I) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Village Communities
            Support Program (Phase I) Project for Guinea were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory,
            and the Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: decentralization is a long-term
            and comprehensive effort that requires political support.
            The major changes expected are likely to meet resistance
            from some institutions. Therefore considerable effort is
            needed for new systems to be established and officials to be
            educated and convinced to accept changes. To achieve
            successful decentralization, champions are required on the
            community side to make pressure on the central government to
            relinquish authority and undertake further reforms to lead
            to effective decentralization including fiscal
            decentralization. On the Government's side, change
            agents with strong leadership and the right vision is
            required to undertake the courageous reforms for effective
            decentralization. Fiscal capabilities are critical to
            long-term viability of local governments. In order for
            decentralization reforms to be sustainable, they need to be
            accompanied by effective fiscal decentralization. While
            local governments have rights over some taxation schemes,
            the poverty levels make it difficult for them to collect a
            substantial share of these revenues therefore limiting them
            in their ability to undertake investment activities.
            Medium-term efforts should focus on fiscal issues, including
            sustainable transfers from the central government.

repnme.cdata!:
Guinea - Village Communities Support
            Program Project : additional financing

abstracts.cdata!:
The additional grant to the Village
            Communities Support Program will cover project scale-up to
            increase the number of communities benefiting from project
            support in order to leverage and build upon a better than
            expected implementation capacity and results to date. The
            additional financing would also enable preservation of this
            capacity and implementation momentum while the second APL
            (Adaptable Program Lending instrument) phase is under
            preparation. The Credit supporting the Project was
            originally extended until December 31, 2005 to support the
            process leading to local elections to replace appointed
            rural development community (Communaute Rude de
            Developpement (CRD)) leaders by democratically elected
            representatives. These elections are planned for December
            18, 2005, and were the sole remaining trigger for the
            Project's second phase. At the present time, remaining
            resources from the International Development Association
            (IDA) for FY06 are, however, insufficient tofinance the
            project's second phase (estimated at US$35 million);
            while it is expected that sufficient FY07 resources are
            available.  Additional Financing, which would have a closing
            date of June 30,2007, would thus also help bridge the gap
            between the end of the first phase and the start-up of the
            second phase, avoiding loss of momentum in the program.
            Moreover, as the project has been increasingly used as a
            vehicle for providing services to communities, two Bank
            operations (the Multi-Sectoral AIDS Project and the
            Education for All Project) will face implementation problems
            if the project's funding is interrupted. Following
            Midterm Review, the Project had scaled-up its geographic
            coverage from the original target of 100 to 146 CRDs. The
            Additional Financing will enable the project to continue
            capacity-building activities, and support the implementation
            and updating of local development plans in these 146 CRDs
            and ensure that the new representative local governments
            have the capacity to lead participatory local development
            planning and implementation processes. Continued support
            will be a stabilizing apolitical influence in participating
            CRDs. Given that the project covers half the country, it
            could become a destabilizing factor if a longer-term
            interruption in financing occurs. After the elections,
            continued support will be necessary to provide training to
            newly elected CRD presidents, who will likely be different
            from those presently in place, as these have been appointed
            by the central Government. In addition, continued support to
            the nascent democratization process implies continued
            investment support to local development to cement achievements.

repnme.cdata!:
Guinea - Village Communities Support
            Program (Phase I) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Village Communities Support Program
            (Phase I) Project seeks to strengthen local governance in
            rural Guinea and promote social and economic empowerment of
            the rural population, including women, youth and other
            marginalized groups. The project's objectives are to:
            1) establish an operationally effective and efficient,
            decentralized system for local development; and 2) increase
            access of the rural population to basic infrastructure and
            services. There are four project components. First, Local
            Investment Fund (LIF) will stimulate local development by
            transferring grants directly to Rural Development
            Communities. The fund will support basic infrastructure
            identified by the communities. Second, support to the local
            development process will focus on improving the
            institutional and regulatory framework and equipping Guinea
            with the tools to analyze and implement local development;
            increasing local mobilization; and improving capacity of
            local participants to take charge of their own development
            and sustain their investments. Third, maintenance and
            rehabilitation of rural roads will develop a strategy for
            the management of the rural roads network, implement a
            priority maintenance and rehabilitation program and support
            the reorganization of the Maintenance Unit of the National
            Directorate of Rural Engineering Services (DNGR). Finally,
            project coordination and management will handle the
            day-to-day management of the project activities.

repnme.cdata!:
Guinea - Village Community Support Program
            (Phase 1) Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Village Community Support Program -
            Phase 1 Project for Guinea aims to: (i) establish an
            operationally effective and efficient, decentralized system
            for local development; and (ii) increase access of the rural
            population to basic infrastructure and services. The
            proposed project has been placed in environmental screening
            category B, and an Environmental Management Plan that
            provides support for a series of practical actions to
            address potential environmental issues has been prepared.
            The small-scale community infrastructures to be constructed
            under the program will have limited negative environmental
            impacts. To mitigate potentially adverse environmental
            impacts, agent de developpement communautaire (ADCs) will be
            trained in environmental management through on-the-job
            training programs. They will help communaute rural de
            developpement (CRDs) screen subprojects for environmental
            impacts and integrate required mitigation measures into
            subproject design. Regarding the rural roads rehabilitation
            and maintenance component, an environmental mitigation unit
            (EMU) will be established within direction nationale du
            genie rural (DNGR) to monitor environmental effects of
            project activities, and propose and implement appropriate
            mitigation plans.
